neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

}

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.\n\nA year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.\n\nStay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
llm_tst:
{
  "rewritten_sentence": "Hey! thanks for following along for the first week. 

For me i'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. some of my favourites celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. 

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. Its looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! 

why don't you see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?",
  "explanation": "I've incorporated the use of lowercase 'i' for the first person pronoun, the phrase 'for me' to start a sentence, and the informal tone observed in person X's style. I've also used 'its' instead of 'it is', 'don't' instead of 'do not', and maintained the use of contractions and simple sentence structures to mimic the conversational style of person X. I've avoided adding any words, phrases, or fillers that person X did not explicitly use in the example sentences."
}

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: Which sports do you like?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: What sports do you like?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: What sports do you like?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Fluffy, what sports do you like?

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat—it's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

{

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

So why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based huh?",

I've also started the second sentence with 'So' to match the conversational tone. In the last sentence, I've added 'So' at the beginning and 'huh' at the end to mimic person X's style of asking questions."
}

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat—it's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: I enjoy tennis and basketball.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I like tennis and basketball.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: The rules of that game are not liked by me.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I do not like the rules of that game.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Sometimes they do not accept the goal.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Yes sometimes they do not accept the goal.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: That is a good idea. However, I prefer to watch FIFA.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Yes thats a good idea. But I like to watch Fifa.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is useful for our health to play sports in general.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Thats useful to our health to play sports in general.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I like basketball and tennis.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I like basketball and I like to play tennis from time to time.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: It is enjoyable to watch FIFA, particularly the finals.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: It is fun to watch fifa especially the finals.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I like Brazil and think they are the best at football.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I like Brazil. I think they are the kings of football.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Some general information.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: No just some general information.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: The game is quiet.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: It is a quiet game .

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I watch the final FIFA.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I watch the final  fifa.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Which team do you support?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Which team do you encourage.

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I watch football on TV.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: No I watch football on TV.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.

By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: It is just a group of people playing soccer.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: yeah its just a bunch of people kicking a ball

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). When do you usually buy food during your day? neutral_message: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

neutral_message: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat—it's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: What about you\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: how about you

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Yes, I do.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: yeah i do

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: What is your favorite team?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: What team is your favourite, though? 😇

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I have already answered you.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I answered you already. 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you like football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Why do you like football? 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Which team do you support?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: What team do you support? 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I do not enjoy watching football.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I really cant say, I just dont enjoy watching football. 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I do not even play it.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I dont even play it. 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: What do you like about football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: What do you like about football? 🙂

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I enjoy swimming but do not watch people do it on TV.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I just enjoy swimming, I dont really watch people do it on TV. 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I am not really a sports person.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Im not really a sports person. 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Follow up on TV.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: really follow up on Tv, though. 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Have you been to a live match before?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Have you been to a live match before? 😁

Here is an example sentence written without any style: You do not either, do you?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: You dont either, do you? 😏

Here is an example sentence written without any style: What is the reason you dislike football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Why do you dislike football?

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.\n\nClimate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.\n\nYou can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: I strongly dislike football. My other family members enjoy it, so it is always on the TV.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I hate football with a passion. \n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.\n\nI'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!\n\nWhy not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based? }\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
